text.name: sys_description
text.text: The TI-99/4 marketed by Texas Instruments in 1979, was one of the first family computers. It had notable similarities to the concept of consoles such as the ability to be plugged into a SCART TV, a cartridge reader, and a connector for two controllers. It was equipped with a 16-bit 3.3 Mhz processor and 16 kB of RAM. The best-known model was the TI-99/4A, in reference to its graphics processor, the TMS9918A. Capable of displaying a resolution of 256x192 pixels in 16 colors and 32 sprites. He could also read and write on audio cassettes.
